qas.question: When Victoria isolated herself from the public, what movement began to grow?
What was the name of the private Estate in Scotland that Albert and Victoria purchased?
What year did the Queen and Albert purchase Balmoral Castle?
What year did a protester attach a note to the door at Buckingham Palace saying it was to be sold?
What private estate did Victoria aquire with Albert in 1847?
Where did a protector put a notice because of Queen Victoria's lack of public appearances in March of 1864?
Where did Victoria visit after Leopold advised her to make more public appearances?

answers.text: the gardens of the Royal Horticultural Society at Kensington

qas.question: What movement gained popularity due to the lack of Victoria appearing in public?
What was a major reason Victoria's monarchy was not as popular as some others?
What did Victoria's isolation give way to?

answers.text: the growth of the republican movement

qas.question: Who advised Vicotria to begin appaering in public?
Where did Victoria visit to become more in the public view?
What else did Victoria do to try to return her former public image?

answers.text: take a drive through London in an open carriage

qas.question: When Victoria isolated himself from the public, what movement began to grow?
Where did Victoria not isolate herself?
What was the name of the public Estate in Scotland that Albert and Victoria purchased?
What year did the King and Albert purchase Balmoral Castle?
What year did the Queen and Albert sell Balmoral Castle?

context: Victoria's <a9_0>self-imposed isolation from the public<a9_0/> diminished the popularity of the monarchy, and encouraged <a10_0>the growth of <a0_0><b14_0>the <a8_0>republican movement<b14_0/><a10_0/><a8_0/><a0_0/>. She did undertake her official government duties, yet chose to remain secluded <a1_0><b15_0>in her royal residences<b15_0/><a1_0/>—Windsor Castle, Osborne House, and the private estate in Scotland that she and Albert had acquired in <a3_0>1847<a3_0/>, <a2_0><a5_0><b16_0>Balmoral Castle<b16_0/><a5_0/><a2_0/>. In March <a4_0><b17_0><b18_0>1864<b18_0/><b17_0/><a4_0/>, a protester stuck a notice on the railings of <a6_0>Buckingham Palace<a6_0/> that announced "these commanding premises to be let or sold in consequence of the late occupant's declining business". <a11_0>Her uncle Leopold<a11_0/> wrote to her advising her to appear in public. She agreed to visit <a7_0>the gardens of the <a12_0>Royal Horticultural Society at Kensington<a12_0/><a7_0/> and <a13_0>take a drive through London in an open carriage<a13_0/>.
